newsitem.title: USA: China ag policy hurts WTO chances - USDA's Glickman.
newsitem.headline: China ag policy hurts WTO chances - USDA's Glickman.

text.p: China's fixation on agricultural self-sufficiency is hurting its chances for becoming a member of the World Trade Organization, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said Monday.

"I'll just say that the latest signals on the agricultural front are not good," Glickman said in a speech. "For the past two years, the Chinese government has been fixated on self- sufficiency and has intensified its role in basic ag commodity markets. This certainly doesn't help their case for joining the WTO."

USDA has sought wide access to Chinese markets for years. It has contended there are unfair barriers against specific U.S. exports, such as wheat, and overall policies that impede trade, such as the role of state trading enterprises that hold monopoly power over imports and exports of some items.
Glickman also said China ultimately would be a grain importer even with recent success in boosting domestic output.
"But it's hard to believe -- given their population demands -- that we won't soon see a return to imports," he said.
